# Water System Interconnections

Water system interconnections are physical connections between two or more water systems that allow water to flow between them. In California, where drought and seismic risk threaten supply reliability, interconnections provide critical backup capacity and operational flexibility for neighboring utilities.

## Purpose and Benefits

Interconnections serve multiple functions for California water systems:
- **Emergency backup supply** during main breaks, contamination events, or natural disasters
- **Operational flexibility** for planned maintenance and system flushing
- **Drought resilience** by enabling temporary supply sharing during shortages
- **Reduced capital needs** compared to building redundant infrastructure

## Requirements

Establishing an interconnection requires compliance with the [DDW Public Water System Requirements](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/):
- Formal interconnection agreement between participating systems
- Water quality compatibility assessment to avoid blending issues
- Backflow prevention devices at connection points
- Pressure management to prevent cross-contamination

## Planning Context

The [Water Resilience Portfolio](https://waterresilience.ca.gov/) and [DWR Integrated Regional Water Management](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Integrated-Regional-Water-Management) programs encourage regional coordination through interconnections as a key strategy for building water supply reliability across California.

## Take Action
1. Contact your water utility to ask whether interconnections exist with neighboring systems.
2. Review regional planning resources at [DWR Integrated Regional Water Management](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Integrated-Regional-Water-Management).
3. Check system compliance requirements at [DDW Public Water System Requirements](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/).
4. Explore the [Water Resilience Portfolio](https://waterresilience.ca.gov/) for state guidance on regional coordination.
5. Contact your Regional Water Quality Control Board for site-specific interconnection guidance.

# Lead Service Line Replacement

Lead service lines -- the pipes connecting water mains to buildings -- pose a serious public health risk. California is accelerating the replacement of these lines through federal Lead and Copper Rule Revisions and state-funded programs, with environmental justice communities prioritized for early action.

## Federal and State Requirements

The revised [Lead and Copper Rule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/) requires water systems to:
- Complete a [Lead Service Line Inventory](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead_service_line_inventory_pws.html) identifying all service line materials
- Implement mandatory replacement programs on defined timelines
- Provide public notification when lead lines are identified
- Submit annual progress reports to DDW

## California's Approach

California has moved beyond minimum federal compliance. The state offers [Lead Service Line Replacement Funding](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/services/funding/lead-service-line-funding.html) through DWSRF and SAFER to help systems -- especially disadvantaged communities -- cover replacement costs. Environmental justice communities receive priority.

## Identification Methods

Systems must identify lead lines through records review, visual inspection at meter pits, predictive modeling based on installation era, and customer notification programs. [LCR Water System Resources](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/water_system_resources.html) provide detailed guidance.

## Take Action
1. Review the [Lead and Copper Rule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/) requirements for your system size.
2. Check your system's [Lead Service Line Inventory](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead_service_line_inventory_pws.html) status.
3. Explore [Lead Service Line Replacement Funding](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/services/funding/lead-service-line-funding.html) for grants and loans.
4. Access [LCR Water System Resources](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/water_system_resources.html) for compliance guidance and templates.
5. Contact DDW if you suspect lead service lines on your property.

# Water Quality Monitoring Equipment

Accurate monitoring is the backbone of drinking water safety in California. Water systems must deploy specific monitoring equipment to ensure continuous compliance with state and federal standards, and all laboratory analysis must be performed by [ELAP-accredited labs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/).

## Required Monitoring

California's [Drinking Water Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) mandates continuous monitoring for:
- **Chlorine residual** -- maintained throughout the distribution system
- **Turbidity** -- critical for surface water treatment plants
- **pH** -- affects disinfection efficacy and corrosion control
- **Temperature** -- influences treatment chemistry and microbial growth

## Advanced Monitoring

Modern systems increasingly deploy online analyzers integrated with SCADA systems for real-time data collection and remote alarm notification. This enables faster response to water quality excursions.

## Calibration and Quality Assurance

All monitoring equipment must follow manufacturer calibration schedules, meet regulatory QA/QC requirements documented through [ELAP](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/about_elap.html) standards, and maintain proper chain-of-custody records.

## Take Action
1. Verify your lab is accredited through the [ELAP Lab Accreditation](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) program.
2. Learn about accreditation requirements at [About ELAP](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/about_elap.html).
3. Review monitoring requirements through the [Drinking Water Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/).
4. Contact your DDW district office for guidance on equipment specifications.
5. Ensure calibration records and QA/QC documentation are current and accessible.

# Drinking Water Treatment Technologies

California water systems employ a range of treatment technologies to meet the state's stringent drinking water standards. The choice of treatment depends on source water quality, contaminants of concern, and regulatory requirements enforced through the [DDW Drinking Water Treatment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/) program.

## Conventional Treatment

The standard treatment train for surface water includes coagulation/flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, and disinfection. These proven technologies remove particulates, pathogens, and many dissolved contaminants effectively.

## Advanced Treatment

When conventional treatment is insufficient, systems may deploy membrane filtration, advanced oxidation processes, UV disinfection, or granular activated carbon. The [EPA Drinking Water Treatment](https://www.epa.gov/sdwa/overview-drinking-water-treatment-technologies) provides technology assessments and guidance documents.

## Emerging Technologies

Direct potable reuse treatment trains, nanofiltration, and electrochemical methods are being evaluated for California's growing recycled water programs. These represent the next generation of treatment capacity.

## Operator Requirements

All treatment facilities must be operated by [certified water treatment operators](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/occupations/) with appropriate grade certifications matching plant complexity.

## Take Action
1. Review treatment technology guidance at [DDW Drinking Water Treatment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/).
2. Explore technology options at [EPA Drinking Water Treatment](https://www.epa.gov/sdwa/overview-drinking-water-treatment-technologies).
3. Verify operator certification requirements at the [CDPH Water Treatment Operator Certification](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/occupations/) page.
4. Consult with DDW before implementing treatment changes or upgrades.
5. Review your system's most recent sanitary survey for treatment recommendations.

# Waterborne Disease Outbreaks

Waterborne disease outbreaks remain a public health concern even in developed water systems. In California, the [Drinking Water Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) works alongside local health departments to prevent, detect, and respond to outbreaks caused by microbial contamination of drinking water supplies.

## Common Pathogens

The most frequently implicated pathogens include Cryptosporidium, Giardia, Legionella, norovirus, and E. coli. These organisms can enter water supplies through source water contamination, treatment failures, or distribution system breaches.

## Prevention Through Compliance

The [Revised Total Coliform Rule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/rtcr.html) requires routine monitoring for coliform bacteria as an indicator of potential pathogen presence. Systems that detect total coliforms or E. coli must investigate and respond according to defined assessment protocols.

## Surveillance and Response

The [CDC Waterborne Disease Surveillance](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/73/ss/ss7301a1.htm) tracks outbreaks nationally and provides epidemiological data. When an outbreak is suspected, systems must immediately notify DDW, issue public advisories, enhance monitoring, and coordinate with public health authorities.

## Take Action
1. Review coliform monitoring requirements under the [Revised Total Coliform Rule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/rtcr.html).
2. Ensure your system's response protocols align with [Drinking Water Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) guidance.
3. Review national surveillance data at [CDC Waterborne Disease Surveillance](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/73/ss/ss7301a1.htm).
4. Maintain current emergency response and boil water advisory procedures.
5. Report suspected waterborne illness to your local health department and DDW immediately.

# Water Meter Technology

Water meters are essential tools for accurate billing, conservation enforcement, and system loss detection. California's [Water Conservation and Metering](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/) programs require universal metering, and modern Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) is transforming how utilities manage water use data.

## Types of Meters

Water systems deploy displacement meters for residential use, velocity meters for larger commercial connections, compound meters for variable-flow applications, and electromagnetic meters for high-accuracy needs.

## Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI)

AMI systems enable remote, real-time meter reading with benefits including leak detection alerts, customer-facing usage portals, more accurate billing, and reduced operational costs. [DWR Water Use Efficiency](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency) programs support AMI deployment as a conservation tool.

## Conservation and Efficiency

Accurate metering underpins California's conservation framework. [EPA WaterSense](https://www.epa.gov/watersense) provides standards for water-efficient products, while meter data helps utilities identify distribution system losses and target conservation programs.

## Take Action
1. Learn about metering requirements at [Water Conservation and Metering](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/).
2. Explore water use efficiency programs at [DWR Water Use Efficiency](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency).
3. Check [EPA WaterSense](https://www.epa.gov/watersense) for certified water-efficient products and rebates.
4. Contact your water utility about AMI upgrades and customer usage portals.
5. Review your water bill for meter-based usage patterns and potential leaks.

# Water Storage Tanks and Reservoirs

Water storage infrastructure -- including ground-level tanks, elevated tanks, standpipes, and covered reservoirs -- is critical for maintaining water pressure, fire flow capacity, and supply reliability in California water systems.

## Types of Storage

Ground-level tanks are most common for community systems, while elevated tanks provide gravity-driven pressure without pumping. The [Division of Safety of Dams](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/All-Programs/Division-of-Safety-of-Dams) oversees larger impoundment structures, and [DWR Water Storage Program](https://water.ca.gov/What-We-Do/Water-Storage-And-Supply) coordinates statewide storage planning.

## Design and Compliance Requirements

Storage facilities must meet capacity sizing standards based on demand, fire flow, and emergency reserve. The [DDW Drinking Water Facility Standards](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Lawbook.html) specify construction, coating, and security requirements for drinking water storage.

## Maintenance

Proper maintenance includes regular interior and exterior inspections, cleaning schedules to prevent sediment and biofilm accumulation, protective coating maintenance, and valve operation testing. Adequate turnover rates must be maintained to preserve water quality.

## Take Action
1. Review dam and reservoir safety information at [Division of Safety of Dams](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/All-Programs/Division-of-Safety-of-Dams).
2. Explore statewide storage planning at [DWR Water Storage Program](https://water.ca.gov/What-We-Do/Water-Storage-And-Supply).
3. Check facility standards and regulations at [DDW Drinking Water Facility Standards](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Lawbook.html).
4. Schedule regular tank inspections and develop a maintenance plan.
5. Contact DDW for guidance on storage capacity requirements for your system size.

# Copper Corrosion Control

Copper in drinking water typically comes from corrosion of household plumbing. California regulates copper under the [Lead and Copper Rule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/), with an action level of 1.3 mg/L measured at consumer taps. Systems exceeding the 90th percentile action level must implement corrosion control treatment.

## How Corrosion Occurs

Copper corrosion is driven by low pH, low alkalinity, high temperature, and aggressive water chemistry. Understanding the [LCR Regulatory Background](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/background.html) helps systems identify risk factors and design appropriate treatment.

## Control Methods

Effective corrosion control strategies include pH adjustment (raising pH to 7.5-8.5), alkalinity addition, phosphate-based corrosion inhibitors, and overall water quality optimization. The [EPA Lead and Copper Rule](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo/lead-and-copper-rule) provides technical guidance on optimal treatment selection.

## Monitoring Requirements

Systems must conduct routine tap sampling at high-risk locations, monitor water quality parameters (pH, alkalinity, temperature), and calculate 90th percentile values to determine compliance status.

## Take Action
1. Review current requirements under the [Lead and Copper Rule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/).
2. Understand the regulatory history at [LCR Regulatory Background](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/background.html).
3. Access federal guidance at [EPA Lead and Copper Rule](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo/lead-and-copper-rule).
4. If your home has copper plumbing, flush taps for 30 seconds before drinking after periods of non-use.
5. Contact your water utility for your system's most recent Lead and Copper Rule monitoring results.

# Urban Runoff Pollution

Urban runoff is a leading source of water quality impairment in California. Stormwater flowing over roads, parking lots, and developed areas picks up metals, petroleum hydrocarbons, bacteria, nutrients, and trash before entering waterways. The [Stormwater Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/) regulates these discharges through Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4) permits.

## Common Pollutants and Sources

Vehicle traffic contributes metals (zinc, copper) and petroleum hydrocarbons. Construction sites generate sediment. Landscaping adds fertilizers and pesticides. Pet waste and litter contribute bacteria and debris.

## Regulatory Framework

[Municipal Stormwater Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/municipal.html) require cities and counties to implement pollution prevention programs. Additional requirements include TMDLs for impaired waterbodies, Low Impact Development (LID) standards, and BMP implementation. The [EPA Urban Runoff](https://www.epa.gov/npdes/stormwater-discharges-municipal-sources) program provides national guidance and [CASQA Stormwater Resources](https://www.casqa.org/resources) offers California-specific tools.

## Control Measures

Effective controls include street sweeping, catch basin cleaning, public education campaigns, and green infrastructure installations such as bioswales, permeable pavement, and rain gardens.

## Take Action
1. Learn about stormwater regulations at [Stormwater Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/).
2. Review MS4 permit requirements at [Municipal Stormwater Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/municipal.html).
3. Access federal guidance at [EPA Urban Runoff](https://www.epa.gov/npdes/stormwater-discharges-municipal-sources).
4. Find California BMP resources at [CASQA Stormwater Resources](https://www.casqa.org/resources).
5. Report illicit discharges to your local stormwater program or Regional Water Board.

# Industrial Stormwater Requirements

California's Industrial General Permit (IGP) requires facilities with specific SIC codes to manage stormwater runoff and prevent pollutant discharge. The [Industrial Stormwater Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/industrial.html) oversees compliance for manufacturing, transportation, waste management, and other industrial operations.

## Who Needs Coverage

Facilities in categories including timber/wood, chemicals, metals, transportation, landfills, and scrap recycling must enroll. Coverage is determined by SIC code and the nature of industrial activities exposed to stormwater.

## Key Requirements

Permitted facilities must develop a Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP), conduct visual observations and sampling, meet Numeric Action Levels (NALs) and Numeric Effluent Limits (NELs), and submit annual reports through the [SMARTS Portal](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov).

## Exceedance Response

Facilities exceeding NALs must implement enhanced monitoring, develop action plans, and potentially install structural treatment controls. [CASQA Resources](https://www.casqa.org) provides BMP handbooks and compliance tools for industrial stormwater management.

## Take Action
1. Check your facility's SIC code coverage at [Industrial Stormwater Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/industrial.html).
2. Enroll and submit reports through the [SMARTS Portal](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov).
3. Access BMP guidance and compliance tools at [CASQA Resources](https://www.casqa.org).
4. Develop or update your facility's SWPPP with current Best Management Practices.
5. Contact your Regional Water Board for site-specific compliance questions.

# Stormwater BMPs (Best Management Practices)

Best Management Practices (BMPs) are the primary tools for preventing stormwater pollution in California. The [Stormwater Best Management Practices](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/smarts/) program and [CASQA BMP Handbooks](https://www.casqa.org/resources/bmp-handbooks) provide comprehensive guidance for selecting and implementing effective controls.

## Source Control BMPs

Prevention is the first line of defense: good housekeeping practices, proper material storage, spill prevention plans, and employee training reduce pollutant exposure to stormwater at the source.

## Treatment BMPs

When source control alone is insufficient, structural treatment BMPs -- including bioretention facilities, constructed wetlands, sand filters, and detention basins -- remove pollutants before discharge. The [Construction Stormwater BMPs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/constpermits.html) provide specific guidance for construction sites.

## Low Impact Development (LID)

LID practices mimic natural hydrology: permeable pavement, green roofs, rain gardens, and tree box filters reduce runoff volume and filter pollutants. The [EPA Stormwater BMPs](https://www.epa.gov/npdes/national-menu-best-management-practices-bmps-stormwater) provides the national menu of BMPs with design specifications.

## Take Action
1. Review BMP guidance at [Stormwater Best Management Practices](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/smarts/).
2. Check construction-specific requirements at [Construction Stormwater BMPs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/constpermits.html).
3. Access the [CASQA BMP Handbooks](https://www.casqa.org/resources/bmp-handbooks) for California-specific design guidance.
4. Explore the [EPA Stormwater BMPs](https://www.epa.gov/npdes/national-menu-best-management-practices-bmps-stormwater) national menu for additional options.
5. Consult with your local MS4 program for BMP selection suited to your project type.

# Water Quality Modeling

Water quality models are computational tools used to simulate pollutant fate and transport in water bodies. In California, models support TMDL development, permit limit derivation, and planning decisions. The [SWAMP - Surface Water Ambient Monitoring](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/) program provides the field data that calibrates and validates these models.

## Common Models

California agencies use QUAL2K for streams and rivers, CE-QUAL-W2 for reservoirs and lakes, EFDC for estuarine systems, and MODFLOW for groundwater flow and transport. The [EPA Water Quality Models](https://www.epa.gov/waterdata) maintains additional modeling tools and documentation.

## Model Components

All water quality models incorporate hydrology (flow patterns), transport (how pollutants move), fate and transformation (chemical and biological processes), and require calibration against real-world monitoring data from sources like the [CEDEN - Water Quality Data Portal](https://ceden.waterboards.ca.gov/).

## Regulatory Applications

Models are used to establish load allocations in TMDLs, derive permit limits for NPDES discharges, evaluate alternative management scenarios, and support regulatory decision-making processes.

## Take Action
1. Access monitoring data through [SWAMP - Surface Water Ambient Monitoring](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/).
2. Search water quality data at the [CEDEN - Water Quality Data Portal](https://ceden.waterboards.ca.gov/).
3. Find modeling tools and documentation at [EPA Water Quality Models](https://www.epa.gov/waterdata).
4. Contact your Regional Water Board for guidance on modeling requirements for permits or TMDLs.
5. Review applicable Basin Plan objectives before selecting model parameters.

# Salinity Management in California

Salinity is a pervasive water quality challenge in California, affecting agricultural productivity, infrastructure longevity, and treatment costs. Sources include imported water, naturally saline groundwater, agricultural return flows, seawater intrusion, and water softener discharge. The [Salt and Nutrient Management Plans](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/recycled_water/snmp.html) program coordinates regional approaches to this statewide issue.

## Impacts

Elevated salinity damages crops, degrades soil structure, increases water treatment costs, and accelerates infrastructure corrosion. The Central Valley is particularly affected, with decades of irrigated agriculture concentrating salts in soil and groundwater.

## Management Approaches

Effective salinity management combines source control, blending of different-quality waters, desalination or treatment, and salt export. The [Water Quality Goals](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_goals/) database provides applicable numeric objectives for salinity-related parameters.

## CV-SALTS Program

The Central Valley Salinity Alternatives for Long-Term Sustainability (CV-SALTS) program is a landmark regional effort to develop long-term salt and nitrate management plans. Basin Plan amendments implement these through [Plans and Policies](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/).

## Take Action
1. Review salt and nutrient management planning at [Salt and Nutrient Management Plans](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/recycled_water/snmp.html).
2. Look up applicable salinity objectives in the [Water Quality Goals](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_goals/) database.
3. Check Basin Plan requirements at [Plans and Policies](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/).
4. Contact your Regional Water Board for salinity management guidance specific to your area.
5. If you operate a water softener, check your local discharge requirements.

# Pharmaceutical Contamination in Water

Trace levels of pharmaceutical compounds -- including antibiotics, hormones, pain medications, and psychiatric drugs -- have been detected in California surface water and drinking water sources. The [Emerging Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/EmergingContaminants.html) program and [Constituents of Emerging Concern](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cec/index.html) initiative track and evaluate these compounds.

## How Pharmaceuticals Enter Water

The primary pathways are human excretion (medications pass through the body), improper disposal (flushing unused medications), and wastewater treatment plant effluent, which does not fully remove all pharmaceutical compounds.

## Treatment Considerations

Advanced treatment technologies including advanced oxidation, granular activated carbon, and reverse osmosis can remove many pharmaceuticals. Conventional treatment is generally less effective. The [EPA Contaminant Candidate List](https://www.epa.gov/sdwa) identifies compounds under evaluation for potential regulation.

## Prevention

Drug take-back programs, proper disposal education, and pharmacy collection events are the most effective prevention strategies. Never flush medications down the toilet or drain.

## Take Action
1. Review emerging contaminant information at [Emerging Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/EmergingContaminants.html).
2. Learn about constituents of concern at [Constituents of Emerging Concern](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cec/index.html).
3. Check regulated and candidate contaminants at [EPA Contaminant Candidate List](https://www.epa.gov/sdwa).
4. Find local drug take-back programs through your county or pharmacy.
5. Never flush unused medications -- use authorized disposal methods instead.

# Microplastics in Water

Microplastics -- plastic particles smaller than 5mm -- are an emerging contaminant of growing concern in California. In 2018, California became the first state to require [Microplastics in Drinking Water](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/microplastics.html) monitoring, establishing definitions, standardized testing methods, and reporting requirements under SB 1422.

## Sources

Microplastics enter water from synthetic fiber shedding during laundry, tire wear particles, degradation of larger plastic items, and personal care products containing microbeads. They have been found in surface water, drinking water, and bottled water.

## California's Response

California leads nationally on microplastics regulation. The [Emerging Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/EmergingContaminants.html) program coordinates research and policy development, while the [Constituents of Emerging Concern](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cec/index.html) initiative evaluates health implications and treatment options.

## Treatment

Conventional filtration removes larger microplastic particles, and coagulation may capture smaller ones, but no standardized treatment approach exists yet. Research into effective removal technologies is ongoing.

## Take Action
1. Learn about California's microplastics monitoring requirements at [Microplastics in Drinking Water](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/microplastics.html).
2. Review the broader emerging contaminants program at [Emerging Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/EmergingContaminants.html).
3. Follow research developments at [Constituents of Emerging Concern](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cec/index.html).
4. Reduce microplastic pollution by using reusable bags, avoiding single-use plastics, and choosing products without microbeads.
5. Consider using a water filter with pore size small enough to capture larger microplastic particles.

# Well Abandonment Requirements

Unused or abandoned wells can serve as conduits for groundwater contamination, connecting surface pollutants directly to aquifers. California requires proper well destruction following standards in DWR Bulletin 74, as detailed at the [DWR Well Standards](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management/Wells/Well-Standards/Combined-Well-Standards) page.

## Why Proper Abandonment Matters

An improperly sealed well can allow surface water, pesticides, fertilizers, and bacteria to reach groundwater supplies. Wells also pose physical safety hazards. Property transfers may trigger mandatory destruction requirements.

## California Requirements

All well destruction must follow [Well Destruction Standards](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management/Wells/Well-Standards/Combined-Well-Standards/Water-Destruction), which include obtaining a county permit, using a licensed C-57 well drilling contractor, filling with approved sealing materials, and filing a completion report with the county and DWR.

## Process and Costs

The destruction process involves removing the pump and casing if needed, cleaning the well, filling with approved grout or cement, installing a surface seal, and reporting to the county. Costs range from hundreds to thousands of dollars depending on well depth and complexity. The [DWR Wells Program](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management/Wells) provides additional guidance.

## Take Action
1. Review well construction and destruction standards at [DWR Well Standards](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management/Wells/Well-Standards/Combined-Well-Standards).
2. Check specific destruction requirements at [Well Destruction Standards](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management/Wells/Well-Standards/Combined-Well-Standards/Water-Destruction).
3. Find licensed well contractors through the [DWR Wells Program](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Groundwater-Management/Wells).
4. Contact your county environmental health department for permit applications and local requirements.
5. If buying property with an unused well, ensure proper destruction is completed before closing.

# Produced Water Management

Produced water -- water extracted during oil and gas operations -- is typically high in salinity and may contain hydrocarbons and chemical additives. In California, the [Oil Fields Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/centralvalley/water_issues/oil_fields/) and Regional Water Boards oversee produced water management to protect groundwater and surface water quality.

## Regulatory Framework

Produced water discharge and disposal are regulated through waste discharge requirements (WDRs), underground injection control permits, and surface discharge permits. The [WDR Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/waste_discharge_requirements/) sets conditions for land-based disposal, while the [Produced Water Ponds Monitoring](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/oil-gas/oil_field_produced/produced_water_ponds/index.html) tracks surface impoundment facilities.

## Disposal and Reuse Options

Options include underground injection into approved formations, evaporation/percolation ponds, treatment for beneficial reuse, and limited agricultural reuse -- though agricultural reuse remains controversial due to groundwater protection concerns and potential long-term soil impacts.

## Current Issues

Key concerns include groundwater contamination risk, surface water impacts from pond failures, the controversy over agricultural reuse of treated produced water, and the connection between injection operations and induced seismicity.

## Take Action
1. Review oil field water management requirements at [Oil Fields Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/centralvalley/water_issues/oil_fields/).
2. Check produced water pond monitoring data at [Produced Water Ponds Monitoring](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/oil-gas/oil_field_produced/produced_water_ponds/index.html).
3. Learn about waste discharge requirements at [WDR Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/waste_discharge_requirements/).
4. Contact your Regional Water Board for site-specific discharge or disposal guidance.
5. Review GeoTracker for contamination data near oil and gas operations in your area.

# Cooling Water Discharge Regulations

Power plants and industrial facilities that use water for cooling are subject to stringent discharge regulations in California. The state has been phasing out once-through cooling (OTC) systems due to their significant impacts on marine ecosystems, as detailed through the [CWA 316(b) Cooling Water Intake](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ocean/cwa316/) program.

## Environmental Concerns

Once-through cooling systems draw large volumes of water, causing impingement (trapping organisms on intake screens) and entrainment (pulling organisms through the system). Thermal discharge also disrupts aquatic habitat and can alter ecosystem dynamics.

## California's Phase-Out Policy

The [Once-Through Cooling Policy](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ocean/cwa316/policy.html) requires coastal power plants to eliminate or significantly reduce OTC use. Facilities must transition to closed-cycle cooling towers, dry cooling, or cease operations. The [OTC Advisory Committee](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ocean/cwa316/saccwis/) monitors implementation and compliance timelines.

## 316(b) Requirements

Federal Clean Water Act Section 316(b) requires the best technology available to minimize impingement and entrainment, with California implementing standards more stringent than federal minimums.

## Take Action
1. Review cooling water intake regulations at [CWA 316(b) Cooling Water Intake](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ocean/cwa316/).
2. Check the [Once-Through Cooling Policy](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ocean/cwa316/policy.html) for compliance deadlines and requirements.
3. Follow implementation progress through the [OTC Advisory Committee](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ocean/cwa316/saccwis/).
4. Contact your Regional Water Board for facility-specific NPDES permit conditions.
5. Review your facility's thermal discharge monitoring data for compliance status.

# Wastewater Reuse for Agriculture

Recycled water provides a drought-proof supply for agricultural irrigation while reducing wastewater discharge volumes. California's [Recycled Water for Agricultural Irrigation](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/recycled_water/) program and [DDW Recycled Water Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/recycledwater/) establish treatment standards and use requirements based on crop type and application method.

## Benefits

Agricultural recycled water use provides reliable supply during drought, delivers nutrient value that reduces fertilizer needs, decreases discharge to surface waters, and can augment groundwater through deep percolation.

## Title 22 Requirements

Treatment levels are determined by crop type: food crops consumed raw generally require tertiary treatment (filtered, disinfected), while crops undergoing processing or non-food crops may use lower treatment levels. Buffer zones and application rate limits apply. The [EPA Guidelines for Water Reuse](https://www.epa.gov/waterreuse) provides federal context.

## Permitting

Agricultural recycled water use requires a Regional Board permit, a Report of Waste Discharge, an engineering report demonstrating treatment adequacy, and an operations plan addressing application rates, monitoring, and reporting.

## Take Action
1. Explore recycled water programs at [Recycled Water for Agricultural Irrigation](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/recycled_water/).
2. Review Title 22 permit requirements at [DDW Recycled Water Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/recycledwater/).
3. Access federal guidelines at [EPA Guidelines for Water Reuse](https://www.epa.gov/waterreuse).
4. Contact your Regional Water Board about recycled water availability for your operation.
5. Evaluate treatment level requirements based on your specific crop types and irrigation methods.

# Instream Flow Requirements

Instream flow requirements protect aquatic habitat, maintain fisheries, and preserve ecosystem function by ensuring adequate water remains in streams and rivers. The [Instream Flow Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/water_issues/programs/instream_flows/) establishes and enforces minimum flow standards as conditions on water rights.

## How Flows Are Determined

Minimum instream flows are set through biological studies, analysis of historical flow patterns, regulatory proceedings, and negotiated settlements between water users and resource agencies. The [California Environmental Flows Framework](https://ceff.ucdavis.edu/) provides scientific tools for flow assessment.

## Enforcement

Instream flow requirements are enforced through [Water Rights](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/) conditions, California Department of Fish and Wildlife requirements, minimum flow orders, and mandatory monitoring and reporting by diverters.

## California Examples

Notable instream flow requirements exist on the Lower American River, San Joaquin tributaries, numerous coastal streams supporting steelhead and salmon, and the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta outflow requirements.

## Take Action
1. Review instream flow programs and requirements at [Instream Flow Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/water_issues/programs/instream_flows/).
2. Explore the [California Environmental Flows Framework](https://ceff.ucdavis.edu/) for scientific flow assessment tools.
3. Check water rights information at [Water Rights Overview - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/).
4. If you hold a water right, verify your instream flow obligations and bypass requirements.
5. Report potential flow violations to your Regional Water Board or SWRCB Division of Water Rights.

# Fish Passage Requirements

California's Fish and Game Code Section 5901 prohibits the construction or maintenance of any device that prevents fish from freely passing upstream and downstream. The [Fish Passage Program - CDFW](https://wildlife.ca.gov/Conservation/Watersheds/Fish-Passage) coordinates barrier assessment and passage project implementation to support recovery of native fish species, particularly salmon and steelhead.

## Types of Barriers

Fish passage barriers include dams, diversion structures, road crossings, and undersized or perched culverts. Many legacy barriers were constructed without consideration for fish migration needs.

## Passage Solutions

Modern solutions range from fish ladders and fish screens to nature-like fishways that replicate natural stream channels. Dam removal has become an increasingly popular approach where feasible. The [Dam Removal and Fish Passage - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/water_issues/programs/instream_flows/) coordinates water rights and flow considerations for removal projects.

## Permitting and Standards

All passage facilities require CDFW approval and must meet engineering design standards. The [NOAA Fish Passage Engineering](https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/west-coast/habitat-conservation/west-coast-fish-passage-guidelines) provides federal guidelines for passage design, monitoring requirements, and maintenance obligations.

## Take Action
1. Learn about fish passage requirements at [Fish Passage Program - CDFW](https://wildlife.ca.gov/Conservation/Watersheds/Fish-Passage).
2. Review water rights considerations for passage projects at [Dam Removal and Fish Passage - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/water_issues/programs/instream_flows/).
3. Access federal engineering guidelines at [NOAA Fish Passage Engineering](https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/west-coast/habitat-conservation/west-coast-fish-passage-guidelines).
4. Report fish passage barriers to CDFW or your Regional Water Board.
5. Contact CDFW for technical assistance with passage design and permitting.

# Ballast Water Management

Ballast water discharged by ships is a primary vector for invasive species introduction into California's marine and estuarine ecosystems. The state's Marine Invasive Species Program, administered by the [CA State Lands Commission - Ballast Water](https://www.slc.ca.gov/marine-invasive-species-program/ballast-water-discharge-performance-standards-faqs/), establishes performance standards more stringent than federal requirements.

## Why It Matters

Ships take on ballast water in one port and discharge it in another, potentially introducing non-native organisms that disrupt ecosystems, damage infrastructure, and impact fisheries. California's coastal waters are at high risk due to heavy international shipping traffic.

## Regulatory Framework

California implements its own performance standards alongside federal Vessel General Permit requirements managed through the [Vessel General Permit Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/beaches/vssl_prmt.html). Ships must either exchange ballast water at sea or treat it to meet discharge standards. The [NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/) provides the permitting framework for vessel discharges.

## Requirements

Vessels must conduct ballast water exchange or treatment, submit reporting forms, undergo inspection, and comply with California's stricter performance standards for organism counts in discharged ballast water.

## Take Action
1. Review vessel discharge permits at [Vessel General Permit Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/beaches/vssl_prmt.html).
2. Check California performance standards at [CA State Lands Commission - Ballast Water](https://www.slc.ca.gov/marine-invasive-species-program/ballast-water-discharge-performance-standards-faqs/).
3. Learn about the NPDES permitting framework at [NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/).
4. Contact the State Lands Commission Marine Invasive Species Program for compliance questions.
5. Report suspected invasive species sightings to CDFW or the State Lands Commission.

# Vessel Sewage Discharge Regulations

California designates extensive No Discharge Zones (NDZs) in coastal waters, San Francisco Bay, Lake Tahoe, and many inland waterways where vessel sewage discharge is prohibited. The [Vessel General Permit Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/beaches/vssl_prmt.html) establishes requirements for marine sanitation devices and graywater management.

## No Discharge Zones

California coastal waters, San Francisco Bay, and numerous inland water bodies are designated NDZs where no vessel sewage -- even if treated -- may be discharged. These designations go beyond federal Clean Water Act Section 312 minimum requirements.

## Federal Requirements

Federal law requires Marine Sanitation Devices (MSDs) on vessels: Type I and II devices treat sewage before discharge (where allowed), while Type III devices hold sewage for pump-out. Vessel size determines specific requirements. [NPDES General Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/general_permits.html) cover larger vessel operations.

## Pump-Out Facilities

Marinas must provide sewage pump-out stations, funded partly through the Clean Vessel Act. The [NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/) oversees discharge permits for marina operations and vessel maintenance activities.

## Take Action
1. Check vessel discharge requirements at [Vessel General Permit Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/beaches/vssl_prmt.html).
2. Review general permit conditions at [NPDES General Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/general_permits.html).
3. Learn about NPDES vessel requirements at [NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/).
4. Locate pump-out stations before boating trips -- most marinas are required to have them.
5. Report illegal vessel discharges to the Coast Guard or your Regional Water Board.

# Dredging and Dredged Material Management

Dredging -- the removal of sediment from waterways -- requires multiple permits and careful sediment characterization in California. The [SF Bay Dredging Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/sanfranciscobay/water_issues/programs/dredging.html) provides a model for the multi-agency coordination required for dredging projects.

## When Permits Are Required

Permits are needed for navigation channel maintenance, harbor deepening, waterway maintenance, and restoration projects involving sediment removal. Even small-scale dredging triggers regulatory review.

## Permits Needed

Dredging projects typically require a U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Section 404 permit, Regional Board [401 Certification and Wetlands Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/) certification, BCDC permits in San Francisco Bay, and Coastal Commission approval for coastal projects.

## Dredged Material Management

Disposal options include ocean disposal at designated sites, beneficial reuse for wetland creation or beach nourishment, and upland disposal. The [NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/) regulates any associated discharges. Material must undergo sediment characterization, bioassay testing, and chemical analysis to determine appropriate disposal pathways.

## Take Action
1. Review dredging program requirements at [SF Bay Dredging Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/sanfranciscobay/water_issues/programs/dredging.html).
2. Apply for water quality certification through the [401 Certification and Wetlands Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/).
3. Check NPDES requirements at [NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/).
4. Begin sediment testing early in project planning -- characterization takes time and drives disposal options.
5. Contact your Regional Water Board and Army Corps of Engineers to coordinate the multi-agency permitting process.

# Atmospheric Rivers and Water Supply

Atmospheric rivers (ARs) -- narrow corridors of concentrated moisture transported from the Pacific Ocean -- deliver 30-50% of California's annual precipitation and are critical to filling reservoirs and recharging groundwater. The [CW3E Atmospheric Rivers Research](https://cw3e.ucsd.edu/) at UC San Diego leads scientific research on AR forecasting and water management implications.

## Water Supply Impacts

Atmospheric rivers are responsible for most of California's beneficial precipitation events, filling reservoirs, building snowpack, and recharging aquifers. However, the most intense ARs (Category 4-5 on the AR scale) can cause catastrophic flooding, requiring careful operational management.

## Forecasting and Operations

Forecast Informed Reservoir Operations (FIRO) uses improved 2-week AR forecasts to optimize reservoir storage -- capturing more water during beneficial storms while maintaining flood protection capacity. The [DWR Atmospheric River Program](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Flood-Management) integrates these forecasts into state flood management operations.

## Climate Change Effects

Climate projections suggest more variable AR intensity, changes in frequency, and shifts in timing that will challenge water management planning. The [Climate Change and Water - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/climate/) program addresses adaptation strategies for this increasing variability.

## Take Action
1. Learn about flood management and AR forecasting at [DWR Atmospheric River Program](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Flood-Management).
2. Review climate adaptation strategies at [Climate Change and Water - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/climate/).
3. Follow atmospheric river research and forecasts at [CW3E Atmospheric Rivers Research](https://cw3e.ucsd.edu/).
4. Check the CW3E AR forecast scale before major storms -- categories 1-2 are beneficial, 4-5 are hazardous.
5. Review your local flood management plan and understand evacuation routes in AR-prone areas.

# Water System Asset Management

Asset management is a strategic approach to managing water infrastructure over its full lifecycle -- from installation through maintenance, rehabilitation, and replacement. Effective asset management helps utilities optimize investments and maintain service quality. The [Drinking Water Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) increasingly emphasizes asset management as a component of system sustainability.

## Key Components

A comprehensive asset management program includes asset inventory, condition assessment, risk-based prioritization, and capital improvement planning. The [AWWA Asset Management](https://www.awwa.org/resource/asset-management/) provides industry-standard frameworks and tools.

## Benefits

Systematic asset management optimizes capital investments, reduces emergency failures, improves service reliability, and lowers long-term costs. It also supports rate-setting by demonstrating the true cost of infrastructure maintenance.

## Regulatory Context

Federal America's Water Infrastructure Act (AWIA) risk assessments include asset management elements. State funding programs increasingly require asset management plans for eligibility. The [Water Loss Control](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/water_loss_control.html) program connects directly to infrastructure condition and replacement needs.

## Take Action
1. Review water loss control requirements at [Water Loss Control](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/water_loss_control.html) -- water loss often signals infrastructure deterioration.
2. Learn about drinking water system requirements at [Drinking Water Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/).
3. Access asset management frameworks and tools at [AWWA Asset Management](https://www.awwa.org/resource/asset-management/).
4. Conduct an asset inventory and condition assessment as a first step.
5. Develop a capital improvement plan that prioritizes assets by risk and criticality.

# Landscape Irrigation Runoff

Landscape irrigation runoff is a significant source of dry-weather urban pollutant loading in California. Overwatering sends fertilizers, pesticides, bacteria, and sediment into storm drains and waterways, wasting both water and degrading water quality. The [Conservation Programs - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/) and waste prohibitions address this dual problem.

## Common Pollutants

Landscape runoff carries nitrogen and phosphorus from fertilizers, pesticides including organophosphates, bacteria from animal waste, and fine sediment -- all contributing to downstream water quality impairment.

## Regulatory Approach

The [Model Water Efficient Landscape Ordinance (MWELO)](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency/Urban-Water-Use-Efficiency/Model-Water-Efficient-Landscape-Ordinance) requires water-efficient landscape design for new development, including water budgets and efficient irrigation systems. MS4 permits include provisions targeting irrigation runoff, and statewide water waste prohibitions ban runoff from landscape irrigation.

## Prevention

Effective prevention includes smart irrigation controllers, weather-based scheduling, proper sprinkler adjustment, drip irrigation for planting beds, and climate-appropriate landscape design. [EPA WaterSense Irrigation](https://www.epa.gov/watersense/outdoors) provides efficiency standards for irrigation products.

## Take Action
1. Learn about conservation requirements at [Conservation Programs - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/).
2. Review the [Model Water Efficient Landscape Ordinance (MWELO)](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency/Urban-Water-Use-Efficiency/Model-Water-Efficient-Landscape-Ordinance) for landscape design requirements.
3. Check [EPA WaterSense Irrigation](https://www.epa.gov/watersense/outdoors) for certified efficient irrigation products.
4. Adjust irrigation schedules seasonally and install rain sensors or smart controllers.
5. Replace high-water-use turf with climate-appropriate plants to reduce irrigation needs and runoff.

# Construction Site Dewatering

When construction excavations encounter groundwater, dewatering operations must manage the extracted water under California's stormwater and discharge permits. The [Construction Stormwater Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/construction.html) and [NPDES General Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/general_permits.html) govern how dewatering effluent can be discharged.

## When Dewatering Is Required

Common dewatering situations include excavations below the water table, foundation construction, utility installation in saturated soils, and basement construction. Any discharge of this water requires proper authorization.

## Permit Requirements

Dewatering discharges must be covered under the Construction General Permit (if part of a covered construction site) or a separate NPDES general permit. Requirements include SWPPP coverage, discharge monitoring, pH management, and sediment control.

## Discharge Options and Best Practices

Water may be discharged to storm drains (if permitted), sanitary sewer (with utility approval), or land-applied. Effective sediment control, pH monitoring, and containment are essential. Submit reports through the [SMARTS Portal](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov).

## Take Action
1. Review construction stormwater requirements at [Construction Stormwater Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/construction.html).
2. Check applicable general permits at [NPDES General Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/general_permits.html).
3. Enroll and report through the [SMARTS Portal](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov).
4. Test dewatering effluent for pH and turbidity before discharge.
5. Contact your Regional Water Board to determine the appropriate permit coverage for your dewatering operation.

# Aquatic Invasive Species Prevention

Aquatic invasive species (AIS) cause significant ecological disruption, infrastructure damage, and economic costs in California. Quagga and zebra mussels, hydrilla, New Zealand mudsnails, and Asian clams are among the most damaging species. The [Aquatic Invasive Species Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/ais/) coordinates state monitoring and prevention efforts.

## Prevention Programs

California's primary prevention strategies include mandatory watercraft inspection and decontamination programs, the "Clean, Drain, Dry" public education campaign, decontamination stations at reservoir access points, and boater education requirements. The [CDFW Invasive Species](https://wildlife.ca.gov/Conservation/Invasives) program manages inspection stations and enforcement.

## Regulatory Framework

State law requires boaters to certify compliance with invasive species prevention measures. Lake-specific requirements may be stricter, and interstate coordination prevents introductions from other states. The [EPA Aquatic Invasive Species](https://www.epa.gov/vessels-marinas-and-ports/aquatic-nuisance-species-ans) provides federal guidance and funding programs.

## What You Can Do

Always clean, drain, and dry your boat, trailer, and gear after every use. Never move water, plants, or organisms between water bodies. Report suspected invasive species immediately.

## Take Action
1. Review state AIS programs at [Aquatic Invasive Species Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/ais/).
2. Learn about invasive species identification at [CDFW Invasive Species](https://wildlife.ca.gov/Conservation/Invasives).
3. Access federal AIS resources at [EPA Aquatic Invasive Species](https://www.epa.gov/vessels-marinas-and-ports/aquatic-nuisance-species-ans).
4. Always Clean, Drain, Dry your boat, trailer, and equipment after each use.
5. Report suspected invasive species to CDFW's Invasive Species Program or 1-866-440-9530.

# Sediment Quality Objectives

California's Sediment Quality Objectives (SQOs) protect benthic communities in enclosed bays and estuaries from the effects of contaminated sediments. The [Plans and Policies - Sediment Quality](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/) framework uses a Multiple Lines of Evidence (MLOE) approach to assess sediment condition.

## Assessment Framework

The MLOE approach integrates three lines of evidence: sediment chemistry (comparing contaminant levels to thresholds), toxicity testing (laboratory bioassays), and benthic community condition (in-situ biological assessment). These are combined to determine if sediments are degraded.

## Regulatory Applications

SQOs are applied in TMDL development for sediment-bound contaminants, dredging permit decisions, site cleanup assessments, and ambient monitoring programs. The [SWAMP Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/) conducts statewide sediment monitoring using standardized methods.

## Contaminants of Concern

Key sediment contaminants include metals (mercury, copper, zinc), polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), DDT and metabolites, and other persistent organic pollutants. The [Water Quality Goals](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_goals/) database provides applicable screening levels.

## Take Action
1. Review sediment quality policies at [Plans and Policies - Sediment Quality](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/).
2. Access sediment monitoring data through the [SWAMP Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/).
3. Look up sediment screening levels in the [Water Quality Goals](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_goals/) database.
4. Contact your Regional Water Board for site-specific sediment quality assessments.
5. Include sediment sampling in any waterway restoration or dredging project planning.

# Bioassessment and Biological Monitoring

Bioassessment uses living organisms -- primarily benthic macroinvertebrates, algae, and fish -- to evaluate water quality and ecosystem health. Unlike chemical sampling, bioassessment integrates conditions over time and reveals actual ecological impacts. The [SWAMP Bioassessment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/bioassessment/) program coordinates California's statewide bioassessment efforts.

## Methods

California's standardized bioassessment methods include benthic macroinvertebrate sampling (BMI), periphyton (algae) assessment, fish assemblage surveys, and physical habitat characterization. The [SWAMP IQ Bioassessment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/swamp_iq/bioassessment.html) tool provides data access and visualization.

## California's Approach

The Surface Water Ambient Monitoring Program (SWAMP) maintains reference conditions, standardized collection methods, and biological indices calibrated to California's diverse ecoregions. The [Biological Objectives](https://waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/biological_objective.html) program is developing statewide biocriteria for regulatory application.

## Regulatory Applications

Bioassessment data supports water body impairment assessment, TMDL development, permit compliance evaluation, and restoration project effectiveness monitoring.

## Take Action
1. Access bioassessment methods and data at [SWAMP Bioassessment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/bioassessment/).
2. Explore bioassessment data through the [SWAMP IQ Bioassessment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/swamp_iq/bioassessment.html) tool.
3. Review biological objectives development at [Biological Objectives](https://waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/biological_objective.html).
4. Contact your Regional Water Board about bioassessment requirements for permits or projects.
5. Participate in citizen science biological monitoring through the Clean Water Team program.

# Impaired Waters List (303d)

The Clean Water Act Section 303(d) list identifies water bodies that do not meet water quality standards. In California, this list is maintained as part of the [2024 Integrated Report](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_assessment/2024-integrated-report.html), which combines assessment data, 303(d) listings, and reporting to EPA. Listed waters require TMDL development to address impairments.

## Listing Process

The [Water Quality Assessment Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_assessment/2020_2022_integrated_report.html) collects and evaluates monitoring data, applies the state's assessment methodology, categorizes water bodies by attainment status, conducts public comment, and submits listings to EPA for approval. Updates occur approximately every two years.

## What Listing Means

A 303(d) listing triggers development of a Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) through the [TMDL Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/). Listing can also affect NPDES permit conditions, establish restoration priority, and create eligibility for state and federal cleanup funding.

## Finding Information

The Integrated Report includes interactive maps, downloadable data, and water body-specific impairment details. Basin Plan appendices contain additional listing information.

## Take Action
1. Check current listings in the [2024 Integrated Report](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_assessment/2024-integrated-report.html).
2. Review assessment methodology at the [Water Quality Assessment Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_assessment/2020_2022_integrated_report.html).
3. Learn about cleanup requirements through the [TMDL Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/).
4. Search for impairments affecting water bodies in your area using the Integrated Report map tool.
5. Participate in TMDL public comment periods to provide local knowledge and data.

California offers multiple state and federal funding programs for water quality improvement projects. The [Grants and Loans - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/) portal provides a central hub for finding and applying to programs that fund wastewater treatment, stormwater management, watershed restoration, and nonpoint source control.

Key state programs include the [Clean Water State Revolving Fund](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/srf/) (low-interest loans), [Proposition 1 - Water Quality Funding](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/proposition1/) grants for multi-benefit projects, Proposition 68 grants, SAFER program for drinking water, and DWSRF for drinking water infrastructure.

The [EPA Water Quality Grants](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water/drinking-water-grants) include Section 319(h) grants for nonpoint source pollution control, USDA Rural Development programs, Army Corps ecosystem restoration, and FEMA mitigation funding.

Successful applications demonstrate project readiness, CEQA/NEPA compliance, matching fund availability, community partnerships, and multi-benefit outcomes. Disadvantaged communities receive priority in many programs.
