# Nutrients in Surface Water

Excess nitrogen and phosphorus in California's surface waters drive eutrophication, algal blooms, low dissolved oxygen, and habitat degradation. The [Nutrient Objectives Development](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/nutrient_objectives/development/) program is developing science-based numeric criteria to protect water bodies from nutrient over-enrichment.

## Sources

Primary nutrient sources include agricultural runoff (fertilizers), wastewater treatment plant effluent, urban stormwater runoff, and atmospheric deposition. Agricultural regions in the Central Valley are particularly affected.

## Regulatory Approach

California is developing a biostimulatory substances policy with numeric nutrient objectives. Currently, nutrient impairments are addressed through TMDLs for affected water bodies, NPDES permit limits, and watershed management approaches. The [Water Quality Goals](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_goals/) database provides applicable objectives.

## TMDL Implementation

The [TMDL Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/) has established nutrient TMDLs for many impaired water bodies, setting load allocations for point and nonpoint sources and requiring implementation plans.

## Take Action
1. Follow nutrient criteria development at [Nutrient Objectives Development](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/nutrient_objectives/development/).
2. Look up nutrient objectives in the [Water Quality Goals](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_goals/) database.
3. Check for nutrient TMDLs affecting your area at the [TMDL Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/).
4. Reduce nutrient contributions by using fertilizers efficiently and maintaining landscape buffers.
5. Contact your Regional Water Board about nutrient management requirements in your watershed.

# Temperature TMDLs

Water temperature is a critical water quality parameter for coldwater fish species like salmon and steelhead. The [TMDL Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/) has established temperature TMDLs for several California rivers where elevated temperatures impair aquatic habitat and reduce dissolved oxygen levels.

## Why Temperature Matters

Excessive water temperatures reduce dissolved oxygen availability, increase metabolic stress on coldwater fish, disrupt spawning timing, and can be lethal during extreme events. Even modest increases can shift community structure away from sensitive species.

## Sources of Temperature Increase

Key sources include thermal discharge from power plants, reduced riparian shading from vegetation removal, dam operations that alter thermal regimes, urban heat island effects, and climate change. The [TMDL Background](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/background.html) explains how temperature load allocations are developed.

## California Examples

Temperature TMDLs have been established for the Klamath River, Russian River, and other watercourses with salmonid habitat. Management approaches include shade restoration through riparian planting, modified dam operations, thermal discharge limits, and strategic water release temperature management. These requirements are implemented through [Plans and Policies](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/).

## Take Action
1. Review temperature TMDLs at the [TMDL Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/).
2. Learn about TMDL development methodology at [TMDL Background](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/background.html).
3. Check Basin Plan provisions at [Plans and Policies](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/).
4. If you manage riparian land, maintain or restore shade vegetation along waterways.
5. Contact your Regional Water Board about temperature impairments in local water bodies.

# Stormwater Fees and Funding Mechanisms

Funding stormwater programs is one of the biggest challenges facing California municipalities. Proposition 218's majority protest provision creates significant barriers to establishing dedicated stormwater fees, while the need for stormwater infrastructure investment continues to grow. The [Stormwater Grants - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/swgp/) program provides one funding avenue.

## Prop 218 Challenges

Stormwater fees are subject to Proposition 218 requirements: written notice to affected property owners, 45-day notice period, public hearing, and a majority protest provision that can block fee adoption. SB 231 (2017) clarified that stormwater is a "property-related service" eligible for fee-based funding.

## Fee Structures

Common approaches include flat fees per parcel, impervious area-based fees (most equitable), tiered rates by development intensity, and assessment districts. Each approach has different legal and administrative considerations.

## Alternative and Supplemental Funding

Beyond local fees, options include general fund allocations, developer impact fees, state grant programs through [CASQA Stormwater Funding Resources](https://www.casqa.org/resources), Proposition 1 and 68 grants, and regional funding partnerships.

## Take Action
1. Explore state stormwater grant opportunities at [Stormwater Grants - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/swgp/).
2. Access funding resources and case studies at [CASQA Stormwater Funding Resources](https://www.casqa.org/resources).
3. Contact your local stormwater program about current and proposed fee structures.
4. Attend public hearings on stormwater fee proposals to provide input.
5. Review your municipality's stormwater management plan for infrastructure investment needs.

# Monitoring Council and Data Integration

The California Water Quality Monitoring Council coordinates monitoring efforts statewide to improve data integration, accessibility, and decision-making. The [California Water Quality Monitoring Council](https://www.mywaterquality.ca.gov/) portal (My Water Quality) provides public access to water quality information through user-friendly dashboards.

## Key Data Products

The Monitoring Council maintains several public tools: My Water Quality (Safe to Swim, Are My Fish Safe to Eat, Healthy Streams dashboards), the [CEDEN Environmental Data Exchange](https://ceden.waterboards.ca.gov/) standardized data repository, and various regional assessment reports.

## CEDEN Database

The California Environmental Data Exchange Network is the state's central water quality data repository. It standardizes data from [SWAMP Monitoring Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/), Regional Board monitoring, citizen science programs, and other data providers into a searchable, downloadable format.

## Using the Data

Researchers, planners, regulators, and the public can access CEDEN data for academic research, regional planning, water body assessment, and public health information. All data undergoes quality assurance review before publication.

## Take Action
1. Explore water quality dashboards at [California Water Quality Monitoring Council](https://www.mywaterquality.ca.gov/).
2. Search and download data from [CEDEN Environmental Data Exchange](https://ceden.waterboards.ca.gov/).
3. Review monitoring methods at the [SWAMP Monitoring Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/swamp/).
4. Check "Safe to Swim" and "Are My Fish Safe to Eat" before recreational water activities.
5. Contribute to water quality data through citizen science monitoring programs.

# Drinking Water Fluoridation Programs

Community water fluoridation is one of the most widely studied public health interventions. In California, AB 733 (1995) requires water systems serving more than 10,000 connections to fluoridate when outside funding is available. The [DDW Fluoridation Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Fluoridation.html) oversees implementation statewide.

## California Requirements

The optimal fluoride level is 0.7 mg/L (per HHS recommendation). Many large California systems are fluoridated, though some communities remain exempt due to funding constraints. The [CDC Community Water Fluoridation](https://www.cdc.gov/fluoridation/) tracks national fluoridation statistics and provides technical guidance.

## Implementation Challenges

Fluoridation implementation has been limited by funding availability, community opposition in some areas, equipment and chemical costs, and the voluntary nature of implementation for smaller systems. The [EPA Fluoride Standards](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water) provides federal regulatory context.

## Community Debate

Fluoridation remains subject to local ballot measures and public debate. Both proponents (citing dental health benefits) and opponents (citing concerns about mass medication and health effects at higher doses) hold strong positions.

## Take Action
1. Learn about California's fluoridation program at [DDW Fluoridation Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Fluoridation.html).
2. Review fluoridation data and health guidance at [CDC Community Water Fluoridation](https://www.cdc.gov/fluoridation/).
3. Check federal fluoride standards at [EPA Fluoride Standards](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water).
4. Find your water system's fluoride level in your annual Consumer Confidence Report.
5. Contact your water utility to ask about current fluoridation status and plans.

# Point Source vs Nonpoint Source Pollution

Understanding the distinction between point source and nonpoint source (NPS) pollution is fundamental to California water quality regulation. Point sources discharge through discrete conveyances (pipes, ditches) and require [NPDES Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/) permits. Nonpoint sources are diffuse -- agricultural runoff, atmospheric deposition, urban sheet flow -- and are managed through the [Nonpoint Source Pollution Control - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/nps/) program.

## Point Source Regulation

Point source dischargers must obtain NPDES permits with specific effluent limits, monitoring requirements, and reporting obligations. The [EPA Point Source Permitting](https://www.epa.gov/npdes) establishes the national framework that California implements with state-specific standards.

## Nonpoint Source Management

NPS pollution is addressed through management measures, voluntary programs, regulatory backstops, and watershed-based approaches. Section 319(h) grants from [EPA Nonpoint Source Pollution](https://www.epa.gov/nps) fund implementation projects. California's NPS Program Plan establishes statewide management priorities.

## Both Contribute to Impairment

Many water body impairments result from combined point and nonpoint source loading. TMDLs allocate allowable loads among all source types, requiring coordinated management across regulatory programs.

## Take Action
1. Learn about point source permits at [NPDES Program - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/).
2. Explore nonpoint source programs at [Nonpoint Source Pollution Control - SWRCB](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/nps/).
3. Review federal NPDES guidance at [EPA Point Source Permitting](https://www.epa.gov/npdes).
4. Check NPS grant opportunities at [EPA Nonpoint Source Pollution](https://www.epa.gov/nps).
5. Contact your Regional Water Board to understand which sources affect water quality in your watershed.

# Groundwater Quality Protection

California's groundwater supplies drinking water to millions and irrigates vast agricultural areas, making quality protection essential. The [GAMA Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/) (Groundwater Ambient Monitoring and Assessment) provides comprehensive statewide groundwater quality data, while the [Protecting Groundwater](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/groundwater/protecting_gw.html) page outlines state protection strategies.

## Threats to Groundwater

Key threats include agricultural contamination (nitrates, pesticides), industrial spills, leaking underground storage tanks, failing septic systems, and natural contamination (arsenic, hexavalent chromium). Each requires different prevention and cleanup approaches.

## Protection and Cleanup Programs

Programs include wellhead protection zones, the UST cleanup program, land disposal regulations, Basin Plan groundwater objectives, and the [GAMA Online Tools](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/online_tools.html) for accessing monitoring data. The [Groundwater Data and Databases](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/resources/data_databases/groundwater.html) provide comprehensive access to state groundwater quality records.

## Antidegradation Policy

California's antidegradation policy protects high-quality groundwater from degradation while allowing some changes where justified. Basin Plan provisions and permit conditions implement this protection.

## Take Action
1. Explore statewide groundwater quality data through the [GAMA Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/).
2. Learn about protection strategies at [Protecting Groundwater](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/groundwater/protecting_gw.html).
3. Search groundwater quality near you using [GAMA Online Tools](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/online_tools.html).
4. Access detailed groundwater records at [Groundwater Data and Databases](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/resources/data_databases/groundwater.html).
5. If you own a private well, test annually for bacteria and nitrates -- contact your county environmental health department for guidance.
